awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Collaborative Research: The consumption rate of a CO2 pulse: Lessons from the middle Miocene
awd_abstract_narration:
As human activity has already produced atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations that have surpassed the highest levels known during of the past three million years of Earth history, it is critical for society to better understand the fate of atmospheric carbon dioxide produced by fossil fuel burning and other human activities.  More accurate projections of future climate scenarios will require a more detailed understanding of how fast natural processes can remove from Earth's atmosphere the pulse of carbon dioxide that is being produced by society in the industrial era. Models of these processes predict a long tail of the pulse of human-produced carbon dioxide, suggesting that this carbon will have a long-term impact on our climate and society.  As these processes play out over relatively long timescales, such predictions can be verified by looking to the geological record of past events. This project will provide a high-resolution reconstruction of how an ancient natural pulse of carbon dioxide injected into the atmosphere was neutralized by the Earth system in the geological past. As such, this study will provide important perspective from the past on the present rate at which atmospheric carbon can be taken up by natural processes, and hence help Earth scientists make more accurate projections of future climate change.  The researchers will also work with a Geoscience summer residence camp for high school students and non-science major undergraduate students will participate in experiential learning in the field on the impact of climate change. Both activities will contribute to bringing students with diverse backgrounds into STEM and geoscience career paths.
This research will evaluate the evolution of atmospheric CO2 on decadal timescales following a rapid pulse of large amounts of carbon dioxide injected into the atmosphere during volcanic eruptions that was part of the Columbia River Basalt Group in the US Pacific Northwest.  At the same time as these eruptions and nearby in northern Idaho, an ancient lake (Miocene Lake Clarkia) was formed when basalt flows presumably dammed a local drainage system.  Sediments that began to accumulate in the newly formed Lake Clarkia preserve a history of these events in the geological record that can be used to evaluate, in high-resolution, the evolution of the spike of atmospheric CO2 concentrations that resulted from the volcanic eruptions.  The researchers will use micro-XRF scanning of elemental distributions to focus their study on the unoxidized, varve-like sediments.  They will reconstruct the evolution of this natural pulse of CO2 using the properties of stomatal pores in fossil leaves preserved in the sediments, combined with information from the stable isotopes of carbon preserved in the fossil organic matter.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Miocene epoch, spanning from 23 to 5 million years ago, was a time of substantial global warmth, with atmospheric CO2 levels reaching concentrations similar to those projected for the near future. To better understand the dynamics of the Earth's climate system during this period, our project focused on the Clarkia Lake deposit in northern Idaho, USA, which contains a unique, high-resolution record of environmental change during the Miocene Climate Optimum, approximately 16 million years ago.

Through a combination of advanced analytical techniques and interdisciplinary collaboration, we developed a detailed chronology for the Clarkia Lake deposit, revealing that it captures approximately 800 years of climate history at annual resolution. By analyzing the geochemistry and paleontology of fossil leaves and molecular biomarkers preserved within the sediments, we reconstructed atmospheric CO2 concentrations and temperatures at unprecedented temporal resolution.

Our results show that this ~800-year time window of the Miocene Climate Optimum was characterized by significant variability in both CO2 and temperature on decadal to centennial timescales. We discovered that CO2 concentrations fluctuated rapidly, with changes of tens of parts per million occurring within a few decades. These CO2 changes were closely followed by temperature variations, with a time lag of approximately 50-100 years. This finding suggests that the Earth's climate system responds to greenhouse gas forcing in a complex, time-dependent manner, with the oceans playing a crucial role in modulating the pace and magnitude of warming.

To investigate the mechanisms behind this transient climate response, we combined our high-resolution data with state-of-the-art climate modeling and statistical analysis. We found that the oceans act as a "heat sink," absorbing excess energy from the atmosphere and temporarily buffering the full impact of CO2 forcing on global temperatures. However, as the oceans continue to warm and their capacity to absorb heat diminishes, the risk of rapid, nonlinear climate change increases.

The outcomes of this project have important implications for understanding the potential impacts of current and future climate change. By providing a detailed picture of how the Earth's climate system behaved during a past period of global warmth, our findings can inform the development of more accurate climate models and help policymakers design effective strategies for mitigating and adapting to the challenges posed by rising greenhouse gas emissions.

Beyond its scientific impact, our project has made contributions to education and public outreach. We have integrated our research findings into undergraduate and graduate courses, developed new educational materials, and participated in summer camps and public events to communicate the importance of paleoclimate research to a broad audience. By engaging with students and the public, we aim to inspire the next generation of Earth scientists and foster a deeper appreciation for the complex and dynamic nature of our planet's climate system.

In conclusion, our project has provided new insights into the dynamics of the Earth's climate system during a past period of global warmth, with important implications for understanding and responding to current and future climate change. By combining cutting-edge research with education and public outreach, we have worked to advance scientific understanding while also promoting a more informed and engaged society, better prepared to address the challenges of a changing climate.
